newsitem.title: FRANCE: Seguin to lead French Gaullists in assembly.
newsitem.headline: Seguin to lead French Gaullists in assembly.

text.p: Philippe Seguin became parliamentary floor leader of France's Gaullist RPR party on Tuesday, a key step in his bid to seize the party presidency from ex-premier Alain Juppe after last week's election defeat.
Seguin, the former National Assembly speaker, was the sole candidate for the job despite divisions and bickering within the Rally for the Republic (RPR) over the unexpected electoral debacle.
"A renovated, reconciled and open movement is now at hand," he told reporters after fellow parliamentarians elected him.

Seguin, who took over as the right's campaign leader after Juppe took the blame for the centre-right's defeat in the first round of voting, has made a formal bid for the leadership of the party founded by President Jacques Chirac.
The RPR leadership is to meet on Wednesday to set the date for an emergency congress to name the party president.
Juppe, who is under intense pressure to quit, has not said whether he will stand for re-election.
Meanwhile, Francois Bayrou, who was education minister in Juppe's government, was unanimously elected floor leader of the centrist UDF.
The Communists, who now count 38 members of parliament compared to 24 before the vote 10 days ago, re-elected Alain Bocquet, who had been the party's floor leader since 1993.
Communist party leader Robert Hue, who won his first parliamentary seat in the election, did not stand for the floor leadership position.
